timeline.bodyText: I think you may want to lock around checking if buffer is null and assigning to it here. You lock around that in your onNext below, so modifying it here without locking will give you a race condition, i think
timeline.author: rickle-msft

replies.bodyText:
Same thing wherever you access this.buffer

In reply to: 425432427 [](ancestors = 425432427)
replies.author: rickle-msft

replies.bodyText: Do you think it'd be ok if I just move the buffer population above the locking logic? The intent was for the waitingForData variable to be protected by the lock moreso than the buffer
replies.author: gapra-msft

replies.bodyText: Uhh. It feels safest to put the buffer population in the lock because what if you get two items emitted really quickly and they have different amounts of data or one of them is the end of the stream and is actually empty. Then we may have entered an if block based on one buffer but are operating on a different buffer for which the conditions are no longer true. But we can also walk through this offline and think about possibilities if you think it's safe to put the buffer stuff outside the lock
replies.author: rickle-msft

replies.bodyText: We only request when we blockForData though so I'm not sure that could happen. We can talk about this next week

In our primary use case, the Flux we care about is the one we return in blob.query - the code that handles that would take in the inputs, and it could return some type of error if the query failed (that would be IOException), or the input validation failed (IllegalArgument), etc

replies.bodyText: Summarizing our offline discussion. Anything thrown during pulling data is legit IOException. For IllegalArgument and it's family we should find a way to invoke validation eagerly (i.e. these exceptions should come from query/queryWithResponse and shouldn't be deferred until someone tries to read from stream).
